newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan bourse ends session nearly unchanged.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan bourse ends session nearly unchanged.

text.p: The Casablanca stock market on Tuesday remained stagnant compared with the previous session, stockbrokers said.
The all-share index closed at 435.31 points, up 0.01 percent over Monday's session.

"Traders concentrated on privatisation bonds because it was the last day of subscription for the privatised Fertima fertiliser firm," said Reda Mellakh, a stockbroker at Casablanca Finance Intermediation (CFI). Morocco offered 30 percent of Fertima's stock on the bourse, equivalent to 690,000 shares, at 174 dirhams per share.
Subscription was valid from 15 to 22 October 1996.
Investors rushed to privatisation bonds BDP2.CS in order to buy Fertima's shares, which led to a value drop of BDP1.CS, Mellakh said.
BDP1 and BDP 2 were launched earlier this year by the privatisation ministry to attract investors to the bourse and boost the privatisation programme.
BDP2 rose 10 dirhams to close at 1,070, while BDP1 lost 17 dirhams to close at 1,145.
ONA Group, Morocco's largest private conglomerate, rose two dirhams to close at 477 dirhams.
Credit Eqdom was traded at 1.085, up five dirahms on the previous session.
The traded volume on the official market rose to 30.8 million dirhams of which 16.2 million were privatisation bonds. This compared with a traded volume of 27.2 million dirhams on Monday.
